title: Iran Flaunts Navy, Forgets US Destroyed Half of It With Small Detachment 30 Years Ago
text:
Trump Shuts Down Reporter Asking Him to Talk About Military 
In touting the upcoming addition of the advanced destroyer Sahand to the fleet, Sayyari said that Iran’s military escalation posed no threat to its neighbors and was simply a policy of deterrence. Iran has recently attained the capability to produce its own military hardware and equipment. 
The Iranians might not want to get too cocky about any plans they may have to dominate the gulf region. Their memories may be short, but the United States Navy’s are not. 
In 1988, near the end of the 8-year Iran-Iraq war, the United States was providing safe escort for critical Kuwaiti oil tankers, which supplied oil for the U.S., Japan, and countries around the globe.   
Determined to dominate the oil market, the Iranians made a point of attacking any tanker from another country. So much for the myth of Muslim unity. 
On April 14, 1988, an American naval ship, the USS Samuel B. Roberts, hit a mine, identified to belong to Iran. The U.S. response was swift and sure. On April 18, the Pentagon activated Operation Praying Mantis. In a single day, U.S. air and surface units destroyed the Iranian Sassan oil platform and half of the Iranian Navy’s operational fleet, according to the U.S. Naval institute . 
Iran’s exercises are taking place in the very region where millions of barrels of oil are transported daily to Europe, the United States, and Asia. Our Navy’s Fifth Fleet protects those shipping lanes. And we are ready. 
If Iran’s leaders would prefer to forget what the United States Navy did in 1988 — and can do again — you can bet there are a lot of people willing to remind them.
